sentence: Shares of clouding computing company Salesforce.comCRM are up nearly 4% today following its first quarter earnings announcement.
After posting in-line earnings and upping its revenue guidance, Salesforce is sure to be feeling good about itself.
Should investors be too?
For the first quarter of its fiscal 2017, Salesforce posted earnings of eight cents per share, which was on par with the Zacks Consensus Estimate.
Today's trading activity is more so inspired by its improved guidance for the second quarter and the remainder of the year.
The company upped its Q2 revenue projection to a range of $2.005 billion to $2.015 billion, which would represent an increase of 23% year-over-year.
Our current consensus estimate calls for revenues of $1.983 billion in the quarter.
Furthermore, Salesforce upped its full year guidance.
For fiscal 2017, the customer relationship management innovator expects revenues to fall between $8.16 billion and $8.20 billion.
This estimate comes in ahead of our current consensus estimate of $8.129 billion.
Salesforce's projected growth highlights its capacity for growth compared to its competitors.
The company's earnings are currently expected to grow by over 350%; the industry average EPS growth is just 4.55%.
Its projected sales growth of 22% also exceeds the industry average, which comes in at 5.05%.
These metrics have helped earn Salesforce an "A" grade for Growth in our Style Scores system.

Don't Lose Your Head In The Cloud

While Salesforce is showing several good signs, it isn't quite a "must buy" right now.
One of the most glaring reasons why some investors may want to avoid the stock right now is its weak value metrics.
Currently, CRM holds an "F" in the Style Scores Value category.
Salesforce is showing relatively weak value-related ratios, especially compared to its industry competitors.
The company currently holds a P/E ratio of 214.60 (Industry average= 18.95), a PEG ratio of 8.64 (Industry average=1.75), and a P/B ratio of 10.19 (Industry average= 4.12).
Additionally, Salesforce has not proven its ability to beat earnings expectations recently.
It has failed to post a beat in the last four quarters, and it has come in behind the Zacks Consensus Estimate by an average of 43.75% in that time frame.
Overall, the outlook for the cloud computing and software sectors remains solid.
Salesforce, along with other industry leaders like Amazon, Inc.AMZN and its Amazon Web Services segment, are displaying impressive sales growth.
On top of these results, forward-looking projections indicate that the market for these services will continue to grow.
The issue with Salesforce is not its product or its customer base.
Instead, the company has shown a struggle to consistently create value for its shareholders.
If Salesforce can trim down costs, boost earnings, and continue to grow its sales, it is in a great position to succeed in the long-term.
For now, this stock holds some uncertainty.
